title: Is the fact that people are always trying to escape communist governments (Cuba, East Germany, etc.) proof that communism doesn't work? - Quora

Tribal mongering question. The question assumes facts that are not in evidence. The earliest migrations and expansions of archaic and modern humans across continents and are believed to have begun approximately 2 million years ago with the out of Africa migration of Homo erectus. Obviously Africa, at the time, must have been under a Communist governmental system that didn’t work? In 2012, Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin paid an exit tax of about $700 Million, and renounced his citizenship in order to “escape” the U.S. U.S. citizens renouncing their citizenship, and “escaping” to other Countries (including highly Socialized Countries) has increased by 500% since 2010. Clearly, this is proof that capitalism doesn’t work? Somalia had no formal, centralized government for more than a decade. Many people “escaped”. Thus, even Anarchy doesn’t work. The Country with by far the most people immigrating to it as a percentage of its native population is The United Arab Emirates. Does this mean that a Monarchy does work? Capitalism, Communism, Socialism, and other ‘brand names’ for theoretical systems of government are not inherently positive or negative in terms of helping or hurting the citizens living under these particular governments. It is the Humans tasked with overseeing these governmental systems that help or hurt, not necessarily the system itself. Moreover, none of these branded systems are, and never were, pure. Communism in China today is more like State dictated Capitalism, and Democratic Capitalism in the U.S. is best defined as a kleptocratic kakistocracy. These brands are nothing more than Tribes; an organized collective operating under some documented framework. Humans are instinctively hard wired for survival. As part of that mechanism, surviving is far easier for a collective than an individual. It is Human nature to affiliate ourselves with a group(s), or Tribe(s). In Psychology, this is known as Identity Theory. When we define ourselves, we do so in large part by asserting our loyalty to the groups to which we belong. Interestingly, Human individualism also plays a role. This is why Tribes splinter into sub-Tribes, or new Tribes are formed, or individuals seek refuge by “escaping” to other Tribes if they feel (a perception in relation to others within the Tribe) overly oppressed, and have the means, ability, and fortitude to do so. Humans have always done this. The flaws in the question as stated includes injecting a ‘Tribal Brand name’ in the place of just ‘Tribe’, that the term ‘people’ (some people? most people? A few people?) is too vague, and no directive of where these people go (Would a person escape Communist Cuba in favor of Communist China?). Different Tribes may work better for different individuals. Individuals “Escaping” from one Tribal system to another has no real bearing on the viability of that system.
